This heralded W-state projection primitive enables satellite-relayed free-space conference QKD by distributing and measuring genuine three-party W-state correlations for secure conference-key distillation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nDirectional Entanglement Swapping with Simulated Skin and Mott Photon\u2010Blockade Effects\n\nAbstract:\nWe propose a three\u2010site entanglement\u2010swapping chain that teleports a Bell state from Alice ([0]) to Bob ([1]) using three probabilistic SPDC sources ([2,3,4]), with non\u2010Hermitian \u201cskin\u201d localization enforced by removing all backward source\u2013detector links and an on\u2010site Mott\u2010like photon blockade realized by heralding on the central ancilla ([6]). By configuring Pythues to optimize the internal beam\u2010splitter network under these directional and blockade constraints, we can sweep the teleportation fidelity of the target \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 state between a uniform \u201csuperfluid\u201d regime and a gapped, localized \u201cMott\u201d regime within a single linear\u2010optical setup.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. Post-selecting six-fold coincidences that pair each emitter Ei with Ei+3 directly yields the fidelity overlap of the target triplet states, demonstrating a scalable network-measurement primitive for modular atom-photon quantum systems.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: PT-Symmetric Entanglement Swapping via Non-Hermitian Bell-State Projection\n\nAbstract: We implement entanglement swapping on two polarization-encoded Bell pairs using a central PT-symmetric, non-unitary Bell-state analyser. At the center we implement a 4-input, 4-output symmetric multiport beam splitter realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic waveguide coupler. Two ancillary photons (from additional pair sources) feed into the remaining inputs of the multiport. We perform photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection on the two ancilla outputs and on the four corner outputs. Conditioned on specific ancilla detection patterns, the joint measurement at the multiport swaps the entanglement diagonally, resulting in a Bell pair between nodes A\u2013D and another between B\u2013C\u2014all in a single multiport interference step.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [pair: A\u2013B]  [pair: C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]\n setup:       [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb multiport coupler optimized by Pytheus]\n detectors:   [A](mode 0) [B](1) [C](2) [D](3) [anc. det.](4) [anc. det.](5)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n- Extends entanglement swapping beyond a single 2\u00d72 beam splitter to a 4\u00d74 symmetric interferometer.\n- Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic structures to realize multi-mode coupling impossible with macroscopic beamsplitters.\n- Generates two swapped Bell pairs in one joint measurement; We also prepare one ancilla photon (mode 4). We inject the two A\u2010side photons (modes 0 and 2) together with the ancilla (mode 4) into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Upon heralding a chosen detection pattern on these three detectors, modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse into a high-fidelity Bell pair. Meanwhile, the ancilla input has been \u201cabsorbed\u201d into the heralding, and the two A-side modes have been locally consumed\u2014so node A now holds no photons, and we have freed up one qubit\u2019s worth of resource at A (the ancilla preparation channel) for later use.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom propagation):\n emitters:    [Bell pair A\u2013B]  [Bell pair A\u2013C]  [ancilla single\u2010photon]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [A-out 0'] [A-out 2'] [anc. det.]\n\nPost-selected on a specific 3-click pattern at the coupler outputs, the B\u2013C link (modes 1 & 3) is left in a Bell state. This accomplishes:\n1) Network entanglement compression: two edges (A\u2013B, A\u2013C) fused into one (B\u2013C).\n2) Release of a fresh qubit (\u201centanglement resource\u201d) at A.\n3) No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely linear optics, ancilla, heralding.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement compression at A using a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_compress_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],  # Bell pair on modes 1 & 3\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  # ensure only A-side modes 0,2 and ancilla 4 feed coupler\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Scale to compress N input edges into M<N output edges via an (N+K)\u00d7(N+K) sub-\u03bb multiport with K ancillas.\n\u2022 Use the freed ancillas for sequential teleportation or network reconfiguration.\n\u2022 Enables dynamic network thinning\u2014vital for large\u2010scale sub-wavelength photonic meshes.\n\nThis new network primitive opens a pathway to resource-efficient quantum repeater architectures on nanophotonic chips.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the idea reframes entanglement swapping as a \u201ccompression\u201d primitive via a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler plus one ancilla, it remains essentially standard entanglement swapping\u2014two Bell pairs at A are projected into one BC pair by a generalized Bell-measurement. To be novel at the PRL level, you need a genuinely new network operation\u2014one that cannot be reduced to the standard butterfly code\u2014rather than just a different hardware realization.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment: Sub\u2010Wavelength Nanophotonic Quantum Butterfly Coding Node\n\nExplanation:\nWe implement the minimal \u201cbutterfly\u201d network\u2010coding step for entanglement distribution in a single sub\u2010wavelength nanophotonic coupler. Two senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold one half of a Bell pair; their partners travel toward a shared bottleneck node N.  At N we wish to **cross\u2010route** the entanglement so that S\u2081\u2019s distant half ends up at D\u2082 and S\u2082\u2019s at D\u2081\u2014accomplishing two Bell\u2010pair transmissions through one 4\u2010mode device.\n\n1) Sources:\n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair source 1 emits photons into modes 0\u2192S\u2081 and 1\u2192N.  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair source 2 emits photons into modes 2\u2192N and 3\u2192S\u2082.  \n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell\u2010pair source emits photons into modes 4 and 5, both \u2192N.\n\n2) Central node N:\n   \u2022 A single 4\u00d74 linear interferometer (the \u201cbutterfly coder\u201d), realized by a sub\u2010wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic waveguide coupler.  \n   \u2022 Inputs: modes 1,2 (the flying halves of the two Bell pairs), 4,5 (ancillas).  \n   \u2022 Outputs: four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Outcome:\n   \u2022 Condition on a specific 4\u2010click pattern at the four detectors.  \n   \u2022 Upon this herald, the two unmeasured photons at modes 0 (S\u2081) and 3 (S\u2082) collapse into Bell pairs with the two remote receivers D\u2082 and D\u2081 respectively:\n       \u2013 mode 0 \u2194 D\u2082,  \n       \u2013 mode 3 \u2194 D\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Both entanglement flows have crossed through the single 4\u00d74 device in one shot.\n\nVisualization (photons \u2192 bottom):\n emitters:  [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla 4\u20135]  \n           \u2193           \u2193             \u2193  \n setup N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n           \u2199  \u2198 first **quantum butterfly coding** for entanglement: crossing two Bell flows through one sub-wavelength bottleneck.  \n\u2022 Goes well beyond entanglement swapping or standard multiport perfect\u2010matchings.  \n\u2022 Generalizes to larger k-pair cross\u2010routing by scaling the multiport and ancilla count.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, A sender S injects an unknown photonic qubit (mode 0) into the coupler, alongside an ancilla Bell pair from a probabilistic photon\u2010pair source (modes 1 & 2).  All three photons interfere in the 3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb linear interferometer.  At the three output ports we place photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  Conditioned on a specified three-click pattern (exactly one photon in each of two designated detectors, zero in the herald port), the remaining two modes (which exit back toward two remote receivers, R\u2081 and R\u2082) carry approximate clones of the original qubit with optimal fidelity 5/6.  The input qubit at S and one ancilla photon are consumed in the measurement, and we obtain two \u201cclones\u201d at R\u2081 and R\u2082 in one shot.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom flow):\n emitters:    [unknown qubit @ S]\u2002[ancilla pair source]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [det\u20090\u2032]\u2009[det\u20091\u2032]\u2009[det\u20092\u2032]\n survivors:   modes \u2192 R\u2081, R\u2082 (the two clones)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A **new network primitive**\u2014quantum telecloning (1\u21922)\u2014distinct from teleportation and swapping.  \n\u2022 Exploits a chip-scale, sub-wavelength nanophotonic coupler to implement the optimal cloning map in a single joint measurement.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post\u2010selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla pair, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014no dynamic control.  \n\u2022 Generalizable to 1\u2192N telecloners by scaling to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) sub-\u03bb couplers with ancillas, establishing a whole family of branching network primitives.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength telecloner 1\u21922 via 3\u00d73 coupler',\n  foldername: 'telecloner_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  loss_func: 'fidelity',        # Our goal is to entangle A and D by swapping at nodes B and C\u2014but instead of doing BSM at B then C (or vice versa), we create a superposition of these two orders: B\u2192C and C\u2192B.  This exhibits indefinite causal order of swapping operations.\n\n1) Sources:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 1 emits photons into modes 0 (to A) & 1 (to B).  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 2 emits photons into modes 2 (to C) & 3 (to D).  \n   \u2022 Two ancilla single photons (modes 4,5) from an additional pair source feed the joint-measurement device.\n\n2) Joint-Measurement Node:\n   \u2022 A single 6\u00d76 linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport\u2014mixes modes 1 & 2 (the B- and C-sides of the Bell pairs) with ancilla modes 4 & 5.  \n   \u2022 All six outputs of the multiport go to photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Indefinite Order:\n   \u2022 Condition on a selected 4-click pattern at four designated detectors (two \u201cBSM\u201d outcomes + two ancilla heralds).  \n   \u2022 The post-selected measurement implements the BSMs at B and C in a coherent superposition of the orders \u201cfirst at B then C\u201d and \u201cfirst at C then B.\u201d  \n\n4) Result:\n   \u2022 The unmeasured photons at modes 0 (A) and 3 (D) collapse into a Bell state, entangling A and D.  \n   \u2022 The process reveals indefinite causal order of the two swapping operations\u2014a new network primitive.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:     [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla Two Bell-pair sources emit photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131) and C\u2013D (modes 2\u20133). A sub-wavelength-spaced 4-input/4-output nanophotonic coupler at intermediate node N serves as the programmable switch. Two ancilla photons (modes 4 & 5) feed into two of its inputs. All four coupler outputs are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b1** at detectors (e.g. clicks at outputs 0\u2032 & 2\u2032), the device performs entanglement swapping across diagonal 1: modes 0\u20132 (A\u2013C) and 1\u20133 (B\u2013D) end up as Bell pairs. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b2** (e.g. clicks at 1\u2032 & 3\u2032), the same hardware instead swaps across diagonal 2: modes 0\u20133 (A\u2013D) and 1\u20132 (B\u2013C). This realizes a **programmable entanglement switch**: one 4\u00d74 multiport plus two ancillas, no active feed-forward, that routes entanglement along one of two paths conditioned on which detectors fire.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom photon flow):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]  \n             \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n coupler N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]  \n outputs \u2192    [D0\u2032][D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D3\u2032] (PNR detectors)  \n survivors:   Depending on pattern \u03b1 or \u03b2:\n   \u03b1 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013C), Bell(B\u2013D)\n   \u03b2 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013D), Bell(B\u2013C)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A new **network\u2010routing primitive**\u2014the first programmable entanglement switch\u2014distinct from fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration for a compact 4\u00d74 coupler not realizable with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post-selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s design space.  \n\u2022 **Generalizable** to N nodes and multiple routing patterns (k perfect matchings) by scaling to (2N + K)\u00d7(2N + K) multiports with K ancillas, enabling hardware-level programmable entanglement fabrics.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch (for Herald Pattern \u03b1):\n{\n  description: 'Programmable entanglement switch via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 multiport (pattern \u03b1)',\n  foldername: 'programmable_switch',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0101','1010','1111'],  # Bell pairs on modes (0,2) & (1,3)\n  removed_connections: [[0,1],[0,3],[1,2],[2,3]],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\nTo implement Herald Pattern \u03b2, one runs the same hardware and Pytheus\u2010generated coupler but post-selects on the alternate detector clicks [1\u2032 & 3\u2032], yielding the other matching.\n\nThis programmable switch opens a new direction in reconfigurable photonic quantum networks and can be extended to larger programmable matching fabrics on chip.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: This programmable 4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb switch simply routes between two entanglement-swap matchings based on which ancilla detectors fire. However, the ensemble already contains a \u201cmultiplexed quantum entanglement router\u201d that post-selectively distributes Bell pairs between different node pairs using herald patterns, as well as various programmable teleportation/entanglement\u2010switch primitives. Merely implementing it in a sub-wavelength multiport does not introduce a new network primitive or measurement concept.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme duplicates the existing programmable entanglement\u2010routing primitives (e.g. the Pythreus\u2010Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router) without adding a fundamentally new operation. To be novel, you must propose a network functionality beyond simple matching\u2010based entanglement routing under different herald patterns."

Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\nES_246\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two photons with four modes.\\nWe want the created photons to be entangled in a four dimensional Bell state\\n\\nPsi = |00>+|11>+|22>+|33> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (with four probabilistic pair sources creating the correlated photons), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\nsetup of photon pair sources: [elements to be optimized]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\nthere are four ancillary detectors as specified by 'num_anc'.\\n\\nIn the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. [anc. det.] are ancillary detectors, which should be measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe setup to create a 3d Bell state setup would normally be easier to realize, but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party.\\n\\nThe standard entanglement swapping experiment uses probabilistic photon pair sources whereas this uses single photon sources.\\n\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two qutrits with single photon sources', 'foldername': 'ES3d_sp', 'bulk_thr': 0.0, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-09, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 10, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['00', '11', '22'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [0, 4], [1, 5], [1, 6], [1, 7]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. This goes beyond entanglement swapping\u2014it fuses two edges of a network into one, reducing link occupancy and generating a fresh qubit for downstream tasks.\n  Step 4: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because we only need:\n    \u2022 Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources (for A\u2013B and A\u2013C), \n    \u2022 One ancilla single\u2010photon source,\n    \u2022 A sub\u2010wavelength 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler (abstract 3\u2010mode interferometer),\n    \u2022 Photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors on all three outputs for heralding,\n    \u2022 No dynamic feed\u2010forward.\n  Pytheus can optimize the abstract scattering matrix of the 3\u2010mode coupler plus the placement of ancilla detectors and pair\u2010source connections to maximize the heralded compression fidelity and success probability.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment: Sub-wavelength Nanophotonic Entanglement Compression\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two Bell\u2010pair sources at the same node A, creating entangled photon pairs on links A\u2013B (modes 0 & 1) and A\u2013C (modes 2 & 3). We also prepare one ancilla photon (mode 4). We inject the two A\u2010side photons (modes 0 and 2) together with the ancilla (mode 4) into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Upon heralding a chosen detection pattern on these three detectors, modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse into a high-fidelity Bell pair. Meanwhile, the ancilla input has been \u201cabsorbed\u201d into the heralding, and the two A-side modes have been locally consumed\u2014so node A now holds no photons, and we have freed up one qubit\u2019s worth of resource at A (the ancilla preparation channel) for later use.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom propagation):\n emitters:    [Bell pair A\u2013B]  [Bell pair A\u2013C]  [ancilla single\u2010photon]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [A-out 0'] [A-out 2'] [anc. det.]\n\nPost-selected on a specific 3-click pattern at the coupler outputs, the B\u2013C link (modes 1 & 3) is left in a Bell state. This accomplishes:\n1) Network entanglement compression: two edges (A\u2013B, A\u2013C) fused into one (B\u2013C).\n2) Release of a fresh qubit (\u201centanglement resource\u201d) at A.\n3) No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely linear optics, ancilla, heralding.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement compression at A using a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_compress_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],  # Bell pair on modes 1 & 3\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  # ensure only A-side modes 0,2 and ancilla 4 feed coupler\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Scale to compress N input edges into M<N output edges via an (N+K)\u00d7(N+K) sub-\u03bb multiport with K ancillas.\n\u2022 Use the freed ancillas for sequential teleportation or network reconfiguration.\n\u2022 Enables dynamic network thinning\u2014vital for large\u2010scale sub-wavelength photonic meshes.\n\nThis new network primitive opens a pathway to resource-efficient quantum repeater architectures on nanophotonic chips.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to conventional entanglement-swapping (and existing multiport swap/concentrate protocols). Entanglement Fusion\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two Bell-pair sources at node A, creating entangled photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0 & 1) and A\u2013C (modes 2 & 3). An ancilla photon (mode 4) is injected as well. At node A, modes 0, 2 and 4 are fed into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Conditioned on a chosen heralding pattern (e.g. exactly one click in each detector), modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse to a Bell pair. Node A\u2019s two qubits have been consumed, and its ancilla channel is freed\u2014thus achieving entanglement fusion: two edges A\u2013B & A\u2013C are merged into one remote edge B\u2013C while releasing a fresh qubit resource at A.\n\nVisualization (photon propagation top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [Bell A\u2013B]  [Bell A\u2013C]  [ancilla]  \n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n detectors:   [output0]  [output1]  [output2]  (all PNR)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n- Introduces a new network primitive\u2014entanglement fusion\u2014distinct from swapping or compression.  \n- Leverages sub-wavelength nanophotonics to implement a compact 3-mode coupler impossible in bulk optics.  \n- Frees up a qubit resource at the fusion node for downstream network tasks.  \n- Generalizable to N-edge fusion by scaling to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) sub-\u03bb multiports with ancillas.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement fusion at A with a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_fusion_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],    # Bell pair on modes 1 (B) & 3 (C)\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  \n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal reduces to entanglement swapping of two A\u2013B, A\u2013C Bell pairs via a local multiport\u2014already covered by existing one\u2010shot swap/fusion protocols. A compelling new primitive is **quantum telecloning**: branching an unknown qubit into two approximate clones at two remote nodes, via one joint measurement.  Unlike teleportation (1\u21921) or entanglement swapping, telecloning is a nontrivial network transformation 1\u21922, has no existing photonic\u2010network realization in Pytheus, and can be housed in a compact 3\u00d73 sub-wavelength nanophotonic coupler with one ancilla pair. Our goal is to entangle A and D by swapping at nodes B and C\u2014but instead of doing BSM at B then C (or vice versa), we create a superposition of these two orders: B\u2192C and C\u2192B.  This exhibits indefinite causal order of swapping operations.\n\n1) Sources:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 1 emits photons into modes 0 (to A) & 1 (to B).  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 2 emits photons into modes 2 (to C) & 3 (to D).  \n   \u2022 Two ancilla single photons (modes 4,5) from an additional pair source feed the joint-measurement device.\n\n2) Joint-Measurement Node:\n   \u2022 A single 6\u00d76 linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport\u2014mixes modes 1 & 2 (the B- and C-sides of the Bell pairs) with ancilla modes 4 & 5.  \n   \u2022 All \u201cBSM\u201d outcomes + two ancilla heralds).  \n   \u2022 The post-selected measurement implements the BSMs at B and C in a coherent superposition of the orders \u201cfirst at B then C\u201d and A strong candidate is a **programmable entanglement switch**: a single sub\u2010wavelength nanophotonic 4\u00d74 interferometer that, depending on which ancilla detectors click, can herald **either** diagonal entanglement swapping (A\u2013C & B\u2013D) **or** cross entanglement swapping (A\u2013D & B\u2013C). This defines a new network\u2010routing primitive\u2014**switching** between two perfect matchings\u2014implemented by different herald patterns in the same device. It goes beyond fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings because it provides a **classically programmable** routing choice at the hardware level, and can be generalized to larger node sets and more matchings by scaling the multiport and ancilla count.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment: Sub-wavelength Nanophotonic Programmable Entanglement Switch\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four network nodes A,B,C,D. Two Bell-pair sources emit photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131) and C\u2013D (modes 2\u20133). A sub-wavelength-spaced 4-input/4-output nanophotonic coupler at intermediate node N serves as the programmable switch. Two ancilla photons (modes 4 & 5) feed into two of its inputs. All four coupler outputs are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b1** at detectors (e.g. clicks at outputs 0\u2032 & 2\u2032), the device performs entanglement swapping across diagonal 1: modes 0\u20132 (A\u2013C) and 1\u20133 (B\u2013D) end up as Bell pairs. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b2** (e.g. clicks at 1\u2032 & 3\u2032), the same hardware instead swaps across diagonal 2: modes 0\u20133 (A\u2013D) and 1\u20132 (B\u2013C). This realizes a **programmable entanglement switch**: one 4\u00d74 multiport plus two ancillas, no active feed-forward, that routes entanglement along one of two paths conditioned on which detectors fire.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom photon flow):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]  \n             \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n coupler N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]  \n outputs \u2192    [D0\u2032][D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D3\u2032] (PNR detectors)  \n survivors:   Depending on pattern \u03b1 or \u03b2:\n   \u03b1 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013C), Bell(B\u2013D)\n   \u03b2 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013D), Bell(B\u2013C)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A new **network\u2010routing primitive**\u2014the first programmable entanglement switch\u2014distinct from fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration for a compact 4\u00d74 coupler not realizable with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post-selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s design space.  \n\u2022 **Generalizable** to N nodes and multiple routing patterns (k perfect matchings) by scaling to (2N + K)\u00d7(2N + K) multiports with K ancillas, enabling hardware-level programmable entanglement fabrics.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch (for Herald Pattern \u03b1):\n{\n  description: 'Programmable entanglement switch via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 multiport (pattern \u03b1)',\n  foldername: 'programmable_switch',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0101','1010','1111'],  # Bell pairs on modes (0,2) & (1,3)\n  removed_connections: [[0,1],[0,3],[1,2],[2,3]],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\nTo implement Herald Pattern \u03b2, one runs the same hardware and Pytheus\u2010generated coupler but post-selects on the alternate detector clicks [1\u2032 & 3\u2032], yielding the other matching.\n\nThis programmable switch opens a new direction in reconfigurable photonic quantum networks and can be extended to larger programmable matching fabrics on chip.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates the existing programmable entanglement\u2010routing primitives (e.g. the Pythreus\u2010Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router) without adding a fundamentally new operation. To be novel, you must propose a network functionality beyond simple matching\u2010based entanglement routing under different herald patterns.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! INSTEAD: FOCUS ON QUANTUM NETWORKS (e.g. take SWAPPING OR TELEPORTATION INTO ACCOUNT) AND INTERESTING TRANSFORMATIONS\nALSO; TAKE INTO ACCOUNT WHAT PYTHEUS CAN DO (it can create quantum networks and measurements based on probabilistic pairs and single-photon emitters and linear optics), DO NOT WRITE ABOUT CAVITIES, RESONANCES, ETC. \u2013 PYTHEUS CANNOT WORK WITH THEM. (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Experiment: Sub-wavelength Nanophotonic Superposition Quantum Router\n\nExplanation:\nWe propose a new network primitive\u2014**superposition routing**\u2014in which a single unknown photonic qubit is coherently teleported into a quantum superposition of two spatially distinct receiver nodes B and C, all in one heralded step, using a compact sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport.\n\n  1) Resources  \n     \u2013 An unknown qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 in mode 0 at sender A.  \n     \u2013 Two Bell-pair sources: one distributes photons in modes (1\u2192router N, 4\u2192receiver B), the other in modes (2\u2192router N, 5\u2192receiver C).  \n     \u2013 A single ancilla photon in mode 3 (from a single-photon emitter).  \n\n  2) Router node N  \n     \u2013 A 4-input, 4-output linear interferometer (the \u201crouter\u201d), implemented by a sub-wavelength-spaced 4\u00d74 nanophotonic coupler.  \n     \u2013 Inputs: modes 0,1,2,3.  \n     \u2013 Outputs: four ports, each monitored by photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n\n  3) Heralding  \n     \u2013 We post-select on a specific 4-click detection pattern (e.g. one click in each of two designated \u201cBSM\u201d detectors and zero in the others).  \n\n  4) Outcome  \n     \u2013 Conditioned on that herald, the unknown input qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 is teleported into the delocalized state  \n         (|\u03c8\u27e9_B\u2009\u2297\u2009|0\u27e9_C + |0\u27e9_B\u2009\u2297\u2009|\u03c8\u27e9_C)/\u221a2  \n       across the two remote receivers B and C. Modes 4 and 5 carry the two halves of the Bell pairs to B,C, respectively. Mode 0 (A) and ancilla 3 are consumed in the measurement.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n\n emitters:    [unknown:0] [pair\u21921,4] [pair\u21922,5] [single\u21923]  \n              \u2193             \u2193           \u2193         \u2193  \n router N:    [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n              \u2199  \u2198    \u2199  \u2198  \n detectors:   [d0][d1][d2][d3]  \n survivors:   mode 4\u2192B, mode 5\u2192C carrying (|\u03c8\u27e9_B|0\u27e9_C + |0\u27e9_B|\u03c8\u27e9_C)/\u221a2  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n \u2022 Defines a **genuinely new network primitive**\u2014quantum superposition routing\u2014beyond standard teleportation or fixed swapping.  \n \u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration to realize a compact 4\u00d74 multiport that coherently mixes four modes at chip scale.  \n \u2022 Fully heralded, no dynamic feed-forward, using only probabilistic pair sources, single-photon emitters, linear optics and PNR detectors\u2014Pytheus\u2019s exact design primitives.  \n \u2022 **Generalizable** to N-way superposition routers by scaling to (N+2)-mode couplers + ancillas, opening a new class of distributed-routing nodes for photonic quantum networks.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Superposition quantum router via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 coupler',\n  foldername: 'superposition_router',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 20,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['1000','0010'],    # photon in mode 4 (B) or mode 5 (C)\n  removed_connections: [],            # allow connections from sources to router inputs [0\u20133]\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [3],\n  amplitudes: [1.0,1.0]               # equal superposition\n}\n\nThis programmable superposition router has no analogue in existing Pytheus experiments, launches a new family of delocalized-qubit routing primitives, and combines sub-wavelength nanophotonics with advanced quantum-network functionality."
}

Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. We also prepare one ancilla photon (mode 4). We inject the two A\u2010side photons (modes 0 and 2) together with the ancilla (mode 4) into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Upon heralding a chosen detection pattern on these three detectors, modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse into a high-fidelity Bell pair. Meanwhile, the ancilla input has been \u201cabsorbed\u201d into the heralding, and the two A-side modes have been locally consumed\u2014so node A now holds no photons, and we have freed up one qubit\u2019s worth of resource at A (the ancilla preparation channel) for later use.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom propagation):\n emitters:    [Bell pair A\u2013B]  [Bell pair A\u2013C]  [ancilla single\u2010photon]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [A-out 0'] [A-out 2'] [anc. det.]\n\nPost-selected on a specific 3-click pattern at the coupler outputs, the B\u2013C link (modes 1 & 3) is left in a Bell state. This accomplishes:\n1) Network entanglement compression: two edges (A\u2013B, A\u2013C) fused into one (B\u2013C).\n2) Release of a fresh qubit (\u201centanglement resource\u201d) at A.\n3) No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely linear optics, ancilla, heralding.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement compression at A using a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_compress_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],  # Bell pair on modes 1 & 3\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  # ensure only A-side modes 0,2 and ancilla 4 feed coupler\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Scale to compress N input edges into M<N output edges via an (N+K)\u00d7(N+K) sub-\u03bb multiport with K ancillas.\n\u2022 Use the freed ancillas for sequential teleportation or network reconfiguration.\n\u2022 Enables dynamic network thinning\u2014vital for large\u2010scale sub-wavelength photonic meshes.\n\nThis new network primitive opens a pathway to resource-efficient quantum repeater architectures on nanophotonic chips.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to conventional entanglement-swapping (and existing multiport swap/concentrate protocols). All six photons are injected into a single 6-input, 6-output symmetric interferometer\u2014realized by a sub\u2010wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport. We perform photon-number-resolving detection on the two ancilla outputs (modes 4\u2032,5\u2032) and post\u2010select on a specific two-click pattern. Conditioned on this herald, the four remaining photons at A (mode0\u2032), B (1\u2032), C (2\u2032), D (3\u2032) emerge in the coherent superposition\n\n  |\u03a8\u27e9 = (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_AC \u2297 |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_BD  +  |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_AD \u2297 |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_BC)/\u221a2,\n\nwhere |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9 = |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. Thus the two possible swap matchings are not chosen classically\u2014they exist in quantum superposition. This \u201csuperposed entanglement reconfiguration\u201d is a new network primitive for distributed quantum protocols (e.g. graph\u2010state routing, network coding in superposition).\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]\n setup:       [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic multiport (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [Aout(0\u2032)] [Bout(1\u2032)] [Cout(2\u2032)] [Dout(3\u2032)] [anc. det. 4\u2032] [anc. det. 5\u2032]\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n- Introduces a genuinely new quantum\u2010network operation: superposed matching of entanglement.\n- Leverages sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiports to achieve a 6-mode coupling in a chip\u2010scale device.\n- Heralded, post-selected, requires no active feed-forward.\n- Generalizable to larger networks: N input pairs + K ancillas \u2192 superposition of multiple matching patterns via an (2N+K)-mode multiport.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Superposed entanglement reconfiguration in a sub-wavelength 6\u00d76 nanophotonic multiport',\n  foldername: 'superposed_swap_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000000','010110','101001','111111',\n    '001100','011010','100011','110101'\n  ],  # superposition of AC\u2297BD and AD\u2297BC Bell states\n  removed_connections: [\n    # only pair sources at (0,1) & (2,3), ancilla at (4,5)\n  ],\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: The superposed entanglement-reconfiguration of diagonal and cross swaps has already been covered. A compelling new primitive is **quantum telecloning**: branching an unknown qubit into two approximate clones at two remote nodes, via one joint measurement. qubit \u03b1 in mode 0 (sender S\u2081).  \n   \u2013 Bell\u2010pair half in mode 1, its partner sent to remote receiver R\u2081.  \n   \u2013 Unknown qubit \u03b2 in mode 2 (sender S\u2082).  \n coupler, mixing modes 0\u20133.  \n\n3) Detection:\n   \u2013 All four outputs of the coupler are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n   \u2013 Condition on a specific four-click pattern (one click in each designated detector).  \n\n4) Outcome:\n   \u2013 Upon heralding, mode-1\u2019s partner at R\u2081 receives the teleported state \u03b1, and mode-3\u2019s partner at R\u2082 receives \u03b2.  \n   \u2013 Both teleportations have occurred **in parallel** through the same device.\n\nVisualization (vertical photon flow):\n emitters:    [unknown \u03b1 @ mode 0]   [Bell half \u2192 mode 1]   [unknown \u03b2 @ mode 2]   [Bell half \u2192 mode 3]  \n             \u2193                      \u2193                      \u2193                      \u2193  \n setup:       [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]  \n             \u2199   \u2198   \u2199   \u2198  \n detectors:  [det 0\u2032][det 1\u2032][det 2\u2032][det 3\u2032]  \n survivors:  mode 1\u2192R\u2081 (\u03b1), mode 3\u2192R\u2082 (\u03b2)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2013 Defines a new **parallel teleportation** network primitive, not just one teleportation at a time.  \n\u2013 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration to implement a 4-mode joint Bell measurement.  \n\u2013 Fully heralded, post-selected, and within Pytheus\u2019s toolkit: probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, linear optics, and PNR detection\u2014no active feed-forward.  \n\u2013 **Generalizable** to N simultaneous teleportations via an (2N)\u00d7(2N) sub-\u03bb multiport, opening a whole family of multiplexed-teleportation network nodes.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Parallel teleportation of two qubits via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 coupler',\n  foldername: 'parallel_teleportation_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 15,\n  num_anc: 0,               # Bell halves act as ancillas\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0110','1011','1101'],  # Bell\u2010measurement correlations for modes 0\u20131 and 2\u20133\n  removed_connections: [],  # all inputs 0-3 feed the coupler\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nThis proposal launches a new class of **multi\u2010teleportation nodes** for chip\u2010scale photonic quantum networks.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal is essentially two standard Bell\u2010measurement teleporters run in parallel in one device. To be novel, you need a genuinely new primitive\u2014e.g. a joint multi\u2010qubit teleportation generating entangled outputs or a superposed/cross\u2010coupled teleportation\u2014not just multiplexed copies of a known operation.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014one that isn\u2019t just another perfect\u2010matching multiport swap or classical entanglement\u2010swap\u2014yet remains implementable with Pytheus (probabilistic pair sources, ancilla photons, an abstract linear-optics interferometer, PNR detectors, and post-selection only).  A promising candidate is **indefinite-order entanglement swapping**: performing two Bell-state measurements (BSMs) at intermediate nodes B and C in a superposition of orders, thus exhibiting indefinite causal order in a quantum network.  This transformation goes beyond standard entanglement swapping, defines a new network operation (a \u201cquantum switch\u201d for swapping), and can be realized in a single sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that Pytheus can optimize.  \n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment: Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Indefinite-Order Entanglement Swapping\n\nExplanation:\nWe distribute two Bell pairs on links A\u2013B and C\u2013D.  Our goal is to entangle A and D by swapping at nodes B and C\u2014but instead of doing BSM at B then C (or vice versa), we create a superposition of these two orders: B\u2192C and C\u2192B.  This exhibits indefinite causal order of swapping operations.\n\n1) Sources:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 1 emits photons into modes 0 (to A) & 1 (to B).  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 2 emits photons into modes 2 (to C) & 3 (to D).  \n   \u2022 Two ancilla single photons (modes 4,5) from an additional pair source feed the joint-measurement device.\n\n2) Joint-Measurement Node:\n   \u2022 A single 6\u00d76 linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport\u2014mixes modes 1 & 2 (the B- and C-sides of the Bell pairs) with ancilla modes 4 & 5.  \n   \u2022 All six outputs of the multiport go to photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Indefinite Order:\n   \u2022 Condition on a selected 4-click pattern at four designated detectors (two \u201cBSM\u201d outcomes + two ancilla heralds).  \n   \u2022 The post-selected measurement implements the BSMs at B and C in a coherent superposition of the orders \u201cfirst at B then C\u201d and \u201cfirst at C then B.\u201d  \n\n4) Result:\n   \u2022 The unmeasured photons at modes 0 (A) and 3 (D) collapse into a Bell state, entangling A and D.  \n   \u2022 The process reveals indefinite causal order of the two swapping operations\u2014a new network primitive.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:     [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla 4\u20135]  \n               \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n joint node:   [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic multiport coupler]  \n               \u2199 \u2198 \u2199 \u2198 \u2199 \u2198 **indefinite-order swapping** primitive: swapping two entanglement links in quantum\u2010superposed order.  \n\u2022 Probes fundamental questions of causality in quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration to implement a 6-mode joint measurement in a compact chip.  \n\u2022 Generalizable: can superpose any sequence of k intermediate BSMs by scaling the multiport and ancilla count.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely post-selected linear optics, sources, and PNR detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design space.\n\nPytheus Configuration (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014no simple swap or perfect\u2010matching multiport\u2014and it must be implementable in Pytheus (probabilistic pair/single\u2010photon sources, linear optics, ancillas, PNR detection, post\u2010selection). A strong candidate is a **programmable entanglement switch**: a single sub\u2010wavelength nanophotonic 4\u00d74 interferometer that, depending on which ancilla detectors click, can herald **either** diagonal entanglement swapping (A\u2013C & B\u2013D) **or** cross entanglement swapping (A\u2013D & B\u2013C). This defines a new network\u2010routing primitive\u2014**switching** between two perfect matchings\u2014implemented by different herald patterns in the same device. It goes beyond fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings because it provides a **classically programmable** routing choice at the hardware level, and can be generalized to larger node sets and more matchings by scaling the multiport and ancilla count.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment: Sub-wavelength Nanophotonic Programmable Entanglement Switch\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four network nodes A,B,C,D. Two Bell-pair sources emit photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131) and C\u2013D (modes 2\u20133). A sub-wavelength-spaced 4-input/4-output nanophotonic coupler at intermediate node N serves as the programmable switch. Two ancilla photons (modes 4 & 5) feed into two of its inputs. All four coupler outputs are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b1** at detectors (e.g. clicks at outputs 0\u2032 & 2\u2032), the device performs entanglement swapping across diagonal 1: modes 0\u20132 (A\u2013C) and 1\u20133 (B\u2013D) end up as Bell pairs. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b2** (e.g. clicks at 1\u2032 & 3\u2032), the same hardware instead swaps across diagonal 2: modes 0\u20133 (A\u2013D) and 1\u20132 (B\u2013C). This realizes a **programmable entanglement switch**: one 4\u00d74 multiport plus two ancillas, no active feed-forward, that routes entanglement along one of two paths conditioned on which detectors fire.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom photon flow):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]  \n             \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n coupler N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]  \n outputs \u2192    [D0\u2032][D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D3\u2032] (PNR detectors)  \n survivors:   Depending on pattern \u03b1 or \u03b2:\n   \u03b1 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013C), Bell(B\u2013D)\n   \u03b2 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013D), Bell(B\u2013C)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A new **network\u2010routing primitive**\u2014the first programmable entanglement switch\u2014distinct from fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration for a compact 4\u00d74 coupler not realizable with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post-selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s design space.  \n\u2022 **Generalizable** to N nodes and multiple routing patterns (k perfect matchings) by scaling to (2N + K)\u00d7(2N + K) multiports with K ancillas, enabling hardware-level programmable entanglement fabrics.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch (for Herald Pattern \u03b1):\n{\n  description: 'Programmable entanglement switch via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 multiport (pattern \u03b1)',\n  foldername: 'programmable_switch',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0101','1010','1111'],  # Bell pairs on modes (0,2) & (1,3)\n  removed_connections: [[0,1],[0,3],[1,2],[2,3]],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\nTo implement Herald Pattern \u03b2, one runs the same hardware and Pytheus\u2010generated coupler but post-selects on the alternate detector clicks [1\u2032 & 3\u2032], yielding the other matching.\n\nThis programmable switch opens a new direction in reconfigurable photonic quantum networks and can be extended to larger programmable matching fabrics on chip.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This scheme duplicates the existing programmable entanglement\u2010routing primitives (e.g. the Pythreus\u2010Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router) without adding a fundamentally new operation.     "output": "Thought:\nWe must propose a genuinely new quantum-network primitive\u2014no simple swap or perfect-matching multiport\u2014that Pytheus can implement using only probabilistic sources, linear optics, ancillas, post-selection and PNR detectors. A promising candidate is **Indefinite-Order Entanglement Swapping**: instead of fixing which of two intermediate nodes (B or C) performs the Bell-measurement first, we coherently superpose the two possible orders. This defines a fault-tolerant \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement links, probing causal indefiniteness in a network. It goes beyond standard swapping or superposed matchings, uses a single sub-wavelength 6\u00d76 nanophotonic multiport (abstracted by Pytheus as a 6-mode interferometer), two Bell-pair sources and two ancillas, and requires no dynamic feed-forward.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment: Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Indefinite-Order Entanglement Swapping\n\nExplanation:\nWe distribute two Bell pairs on links A\u2013B and C\u2013D via probabilistic photon-pair sources:\n \u2022 Pair 1: modes 0\u2192A, 1\u2192B  \n \u2022 Pair 2: modes 2\u2192C, 3\u2192D  \n\nOur goal is to entangle A and D by Bell-measurements at B and C\u2014but in a coherent superposition of the two orders (B\u2192C vs. C\u2192B). We harness a **6-input, 6-output sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport coupler** as the joint-measurement device:\n\n1) Resources into the multiport:\n   \u2013 Mode 1 (B-side of pair 1)  \n   \u2013 Mode 2 (C-side of pair 2)  \n   \u2013 Two ancilla single photons (modes 4 & 5) from an additional pair source.  \n   \u2013 The remaining two inputs (modes 0 & 3) bypass the coupler and serve as the remote \u201csurvivors\u201d at A and D.\n\n2) All six outputs are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors.  \n3) We post-select on a specific 4-click pattern (two ancilla heralds + two \u201cBSM outcome\u201d clicks).  \n4) Conditioned on this herald, modes 0 and 3 (at A and D) collapse onto a Bell state. Crucially, the 6\u00d76 interferometer and detection enforce a coherent superposition of \u201cfirst Bell-measurement at B then at C\u201d and \u201cfirst at C then at B.\u201d This realizes **indefinite-order entanglement swapping** in one chip-scale step.\n\nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla 4\u20135]  \n             \u2193          \u2193           \u2193  \n multiport N: [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n detectors:   [D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D4\u2032][D5\u2032]  \n survivors:   mode 0\u2192A, mode 3\u2192D (now entangled)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 Defines the first **indefinite-order swapping** primitive for quantum networks\u2014probes causal superposition of measurement order.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration to implement a 6-mode joint measurement in a compact device.  \n\u2022 Heralded and post-selected\u2014uses only probabilistic pair sources, ancillas, an abstract linear-optics multiport, and PNR detectors\u2014no dynamic control.  \n\u2022 Generalizable to superpose any sequence of k Bell-measurements by scaling the multiport and ancillas, opening a new family of causal-indefinite network operations.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Indefinite-order entanglement swapping via sub-\u03bb 6\u00d76 multiport',\n  foldername: 'indef_order_swap',\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 20,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],  # Bell on modes 0 & 3\n  removed_connections: [\n    # only modes (1,2,4,5) feed the coupler inputs\n  ],\n  number_resolving: True\n}"

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Realization of the Measurement-Only Braiding Superchannel for Two Logical Majorana Qubits\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose an experiment targeting the implementation of the measurement-only braiding superchannel \ud835\udd05 on two logical Majorana qubits encoded in four dual-rail photonic modes. By employing entangled ancilla photon-pair sources, a configurable multiport interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters, and heralded number-resolving detection, our purely linear-optical protocol enacts the non-unitary Kraus decomposition of the anyonic braid map without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Passive Linear-Optical Universal 1\u21922 Qutrit Telecloner\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a passive, measurement-based linear-optical network that implements the universal 1\u21922 telecloning of an arbitrary single-qutrit state by interfering the unknown input with three d = 3 Bell-pair ancillas via two tritter multiports and post-selecting on a specific six-fold detector-click pattern. Upon heralding, the remaining unmeasured modes on systems B and C each carry an optimal approximate clone (fidelity 5/6) without any active feed-forward or nonlinear elements, demonstrating the first high-dimensional telecloning primitive in linear optics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Optical Syndrome Extraction for a 2\u00d72 Toric Code Patch\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive, heralded linear-optical network that non-demolitionally extracts all four Z- and X-type stabilizer syndromes of a minimal 2\u00d72 toric code patch in a single round, explicitly targeting an arbitrary 4-qubit logical state on data ports 0\u20133. Some parallels can be ok, but the goal should be to have an actually novel experiment with a novel target. You should also reject proposals that are trivial extensions of known experiments. If you can, point out the exact experiment or result as a reason for your rejection.\n\nYou have two possible actions 'accept' and 'reject'\n\n\nYou can only respond with a single complete\n\"Thought, Action, Action Input\".\n\nComplete format (don't use additional formatting such as bold text):\n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'reject')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for rejecting the idea and what has to be improved.)\n\nOR \n\nThought: (reflect on the idea given by the researcher and whether it can be considered novel.)\nAction: (the action name, should be 'accept')\nAction Input: (express your reasoning for accepting the idea.)\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment: Entanglement\u2010Swapping Across Diagonals with a Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport\n\nExplanation:\nWe consider four network nodes A,B,C,D arranged in a 2\u00d72 grid. Two Bell pairs are generated at the original horizontal links A\u2013B and C\u2013D via probabilistic photon-pair sources. At the center we implement a 4-input, 4-output symmetric multiport beam splitter realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic waveguide coupler. Two ancillary photons (from additional pair sources) feed into the remaining inputs of the multiport. We perform photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detection on the two ancilla outputs and on the four corner outputs. Conditioned on specific ancilla detection patterns, the joint measurement at the multiport swaps the entanglement diagonally, resulting in a Bell pair between nodes A\u2013D and another between B\u2013C\u2014all in a single multiport interference step.\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [pair: A\u2013B]  [pair: C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]\n setup:       [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb multiport coupler optimized by Pytheus]\n detectors:   [A](mode 0) [B](1) [C](2) [D](3) [anc. det.](4) [anc. det.](5)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n- Extends entanglement swapping beyond a single 2\u00d72 beam splitter to a 4\u00d74 symmetric interferometer.\n- Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic structures to realize multi-mode coupling impossible with macroscopic beamsplitters.\n- Generates two swapped Bell pairs in one joint measurement; can be generalized to larger lattices or higher dimensions by using larger multiports.\n- Independent of physical encoding, Pytheus will optimize the abstract 4-mode interferometer + ancillas to maximize swap fidelity and heralding probability.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Diagonal entanglement swapping via sub-\u03bb nanophotonic 4\u00d74 multiport',\n  foldername: 'subwavelength_diagonal_swap',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],  # product of Bell states across modes (0,3) and (1,2)\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,2],[1,3]],  # only sources at (0,1) and (2,3)\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal merely realizes a 4\u00d74 multiport\u2013based entanglement swap that projects two Bell pairs onto the diagonal pairings A\u2013D and B\u2013C in one shot. However, the ensemble suggestion \u201cSuperposed Perfect-Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four-Node Photonic Circuit\u201d already uses a static 4\u00d74 interferometer on four photon-pair sources plus ancillas to herald and control all perfect\u2010matching swap configurations \u2014 including the AD & BC pairing \u2014 in a single measurement. Restricting that superposition down to just the diagonal matching does not introduce sufficient novelty (the on-chip multiport, the heralded pattern, the single\u2010shot multi\u2010Bell\u2010pair swap are all already covered). You would need a genuinely new twist (e.g. a swap that cannot be formulated as one of the perfect\u2010matchings, or a new resource scaling, or a radically different encoding/measurement principle) to lift this to PRL level.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme is too close to the \u201cSuperposed Perfect\u2010Matching Entanglement Swaps in a Four\u2010Node Photonic Circuit\u201d multiport protocol.
