We also prepare one ancilla photon (mode 4). We inject the two A\u2010side photons (modes 0 and 2) together with the ancilla (mode 4) into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Upon heralding a chosen detection pattern on these three detectors, modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse into a high-fidelity Bell pair. Meanwhile, the ancilla input has been \u201cabsorbed\u201d into the heralding, and the two A-side modes have been locally consumed\u2014so node A now holds no photons, and we have freed up one qubit\u2019s worth of resource at A (the ancilla preparation channel) for later use.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom propagation):\n emitters:    [Bell pair A\u2013B]  [Bell pair A\u2013C]  [ancilla single\u2010photon]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [A-out 0'] [A-out 2'] [anc. det.]\n\nPost-selected on a specific 3-click pattern at the coupler outputs, the B\u2013C link (modes 1 & 3) is left in a Bell state. This accomplishes:\n1) Network entanglement compression: two edges (A\u2013B, A\u2013C) fused into one (B\u2013C).\n2) Release of a fresh qubit (\u201centanglement resource\u201d) at A.\n3) No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely linear optics, ancilla, heralding.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement compression at A using a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_compress_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],  # Bell pair on modes 1 & 3\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  # ensure only A-side modes 0,2 and ancilla 4 feed coupler\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Scale to compress N input edges into M<N output edges via an (N+K)\u00d7(N+K) sub-\u03bb multiport with K ancillas.\n\u2022 Use the freed ancillas for sequential teleportation or network reconfiguration.\n\u2022 Enables dynamic network thinning\u2014vital for large\u2010scale sub-wavelength photonic meshes.\n\nThis new network primitive opens a pathway to resource-efficient quantum repeater architectures on nanophotonic chips.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the idea reframes entanglement swapping as a \u201ccompression\u201d primitive via a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler plus one ancilla, it remains essentially standard entanglement swapping\u2014two Bell pairs at A are projected into one BC pair by a generalized Bell-measurement. Similar multiport\u2010based swap and concentration schemes already appear in ensemble suggestions (e.g. cyclic entanglement shifters or one\u2010shot swap-and-concentrate repeaters). This does not introduce a genuinely new network primitive or measurement principle beyond known ancilla-assisted swap variants.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to conventional entanglement-swapping (and existing multiport swap/concentrate protocols). To be novel, propose a fundamentally different joint measurement or resource transformation\u2014one that cannot be reduced to a Bell-swap with ancilla\u2014such as a new non-trivial multi-edge fusion not covered by perfect matchings or cyclic shifters.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment: Sub-wavelength Nanophotonic Entanglement Fusion\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two Bell-pair sources at node A, creating entangled photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0 & 1) and A\u2013C (modes 2 & 3). An ancilla photon (mode 4) is injected as well. At node A, modes 0, 2 and 4 are fed into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Conditioned on a chosen heralding pattern (e.g. exactly one click in each detector), modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse to a Bell pair. Node A\u2019s two qubits have been consumed, and its ancilla channel is freed\u2014thus achieving entanglement fusion: two edges A\u2013B & A\u2013C are merged into one remote edge B\u2013C while releasing a fresh qubit resource at A.\n\nVisualization (photon propagation top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [Bell A\u2013B]  [Bell A\u2013C]  [ancilla]  \n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n detectors:   [output0]  [output1]  [output2]  (all PNR)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n- Introduces a new network primitive\u2014entanglement fusion\u2014distinct from swapping or compression.  \n- Leverages sub-wavelength nanophotonics to implement a compact 3-mode coupler impossible in bulk optics.  \n- Frees up a qubit resource at the fusion node for downstream network tasks.  \n- Generalizable to N-edge fusion by scaling to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) sub-\u03bb multiports with ancillas.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement fusion at A with a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_fusion_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],    # Bell pair on modes 1 (B) & 3 (C)\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  \n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While this framing calls it \u201centanglement fusion,\u201d it is fundamentally a two\u2010Bell\u2010pair entanglement swap (Bell\u2010measurement) at node A with an ancilla photon. All six photons are injected into a single 6-input, 6-output symmetric interferometer\u2014realized by a sub\u2010wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport. We perform photon-number-resolving detection on the two ancilla outputs (modes 4\u2032,5\u2032) and post\u2010select on a specific two-click pattern. Conditioned on this herald, the four remaining photons at A (mode0\u2032), B (1\u2032), C (2\u2032), D (3\u2032) emerge in the coherent superposition\n\n  |\u03a8\u27e9 = (|\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_AC \u2297 |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_BD  +  |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_AD \u2297 |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9_BC)/\u221a2,\n\nwhere |\u03c8\u207a\u27e9 = |00\u27e9+|11\u27e9. Thus the two possible swap matchings are not chosen classically\u2014they exist in quantum superposition. This \u201csuperposed entanglement reconfiguration\u201d is a new network primitive for distributed quantum protocols (e.g. graph\u2010state routing, network coding in superposition).\n\nVisualization (photons propagate top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]\n setup:       [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic multiport (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [Aout(0\u2032)] [Bout(1\u2032)] [Cout(2\u2032)] [Dout(3\u2032)] [anc. det. 4\u2032] [anc. det. 5\u2032]\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n- Introduces a genuinely new quantum\u2010network operation: superposed matching of entanglement.\n- Leverages sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiports to achieve a 6-mode coupling in a chip\u2010scale device.\n- Heralded, post-selected, requires no active feed-forward.\n- Generalizable to larger networks: N input pairs + K ancillas \u2192 superposition of multiple matching patterns via an (2N+K)-mode multiport.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Superposed entanglement reconfiguration in a sub-wavelength 6\u00d76 nanophotonic multiport',\n  foldername: 'superposed_swap_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: [\n    '000000','010110','101001','111111',\n    '001100','011010','100011','110101'\n  ],  # Our goal is to **cross\u2010route** the two Bell flows (S\u2081\u2192D\u2082 and S\u2082\u2192D\u2081) in a single joint measurement at that bottleneck, rather than two serial swaps.\n\n1) Sources:\n  \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source 1 emits photons in modes (0\u2192S\u2081, 1\u2192N).  \n  \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source 2 emits photons in modes (2\u2192N, 3\u2192S\u2082).  \n  \u2013 Ancilla Bell\u2010pair source emits photons in modes (4,5) both \u2192N.\n\n2) Central node N:\n  \u2013 A single 4\u2010input, 4\u2010output linear interferometer (the \u201cbutterfly coder\u201d) realized by sub\u2010wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic waveguides.  \n  \u2013 Inputs: modes 1,2 (the in\u2010flight halves of the two Bell pairs) and ancilla modes 4,5.  \n  \u2013 Outputs: 4 ports; all four are measured with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Routing:\n  \u2013 Condition on a chosen 4-click pattern at the four detectors.  \n  \u2013 Upon that herald, the unmeasured halves at S\u2081 (mode 0) and at S\u2082 (mode 3) are now each entangled with the distant receivers D\u2082 and D\u2081 respectively:\n      \u2022 mode 0 \u2194 D\u2082  (Bell pair #1 routed across),  \n      \u2022 mode 3 \u2194 D\u2081  (Bell pair #2 routed across),  \n    achieving simultaneous crossed entanglement in one shot.\n\nVisualization (photons travel fuses two crossing entanglement flows into a single multiport measurement, generalizing entanglement swapping to the butterfly topology.  \n\u2013 **Sub-wavelength integration**: A chip-scale 4\u00d74 coupler with waveguides placed below the diffraction limit implements the required 4-mode unitary.  \n\u2013 **Generalizable**: Larger network\u2010coding operations (e.g. k\u2010pair cross\u2010routing) can be built by scaling the multiport and ancilla overhead, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics abstraction.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Butterfly At N we wish to **cross\u2010route** the entanglement so that S\u2081\u2019s distant half ends up at D\u2082 and S\u2082\u2019s at D\u2081\u2014accomplishing two Bell\u2010pair transmissions through A sender S injects an unknown photonic qubit (mode 0) into the coupler, alongside an ancilla Bell pair from a probabilistic photon\u2010pair source (modes 1 & 2).  All three photons interfere in the 3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb linear interferometer.  At the three output ports we place photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  Conditioned on a specified three-click pattern (exactly one photon in each of two designated detectors, zero in the herald port), the remaining two modes (which exit back toward two remote receivers, R\u2081 and R\u2082) carry approximate clones of the original qubit with optimal fidelity 5/6.  The input qubit at S and one ancilla photon are consumed in the measurement, and we obtain two \u201cclones\u201d at R\u2081 and R\u2082 in one shot.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom flow):\n emitters:    [unknown qubit @ S]\u2002[ancilla pair source]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [det\u20090\u2032]\u2009[det\u20091\u2032]\u2009[det\u20092\u2032]\n survivors:   modes \u2192 R\u2081, R\u2082 (the two clones)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A **new network primitive**\u2014quantum telecloning (1\u21922)\u2014distinct from teleportation and swapping.  \n\u2022 Exploits a chip-scale, sub-wavelength nanophotonic coupler to implement the optimal cloning map in a single joint measurement.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post\u2010selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla pair, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014no dynamic control.  \n\u2022 Generalizable to 1\u2192N telecloners by scaling to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) sub-\u03bb couplers with ancillas, establishing a whole family of branching network primitives.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength telecloner 1\u21922 via 3\u00d73 coupler',\n  foldername: 'telecloner_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  loss_func: 'fidelity',        # All the core elements\u2014Bell measurements, heralded teleportation using ancilla EPR pairs, and multiport implementations\u2014are well established (see dual\u2010destination and multi\u2010destination teleportation routers in the ensemble). To be novel, you need a genuinely new primitive\u2014e.g. a joint multi\u2010qubit teleportation generating entangled outputs or a superposed/cross\u2010coupled teleportation\u2014not just multiplexed copies of a known operation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment: Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Indefinite-Order Entanglement Swapping\n\nExplanation:\nWe distribute two Bell pairs on links A\u2013B and C\u2013D.  Our goal is to entangle A and D by swapping at nodes B and C\u2014but instead of doing BSM at B then C (or vice versa), we create a superposition of these two orders: B\u2192C and C\u2192B.  This exhibits indefinite causal order of swapping operations.\n\n1) Sources:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 1 emits photons into modes 0 (to A) & 1 (to B).  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 2 emits photons into modes 2 (to C) & 3 (to D).  \n   \u2022 Two ancilla single photons (modes 4,5) from an additional pair source feed the joint-measurement device.\n\n2) Joint-Measurement Node:\n   \u2022 A single 6\u00d76 linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport\u2014mixes modes 1 & 2 (the B- and C-sides of the Bell pairs) with ancilla modes 4 & 5.  \n   \u2022 All six outputs of the multiport go to photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Indefinite Order:\n   \u2022 Condition on a selected 4-click pattern at four designated detectors (two \u201cBSM\u201d outcomes + two ancilla heralds).  \n   \u2022 The post-selected measurement implements the BSMs at B and C in a coherent superposition of the orders \u201cfirst at B then C\u201d and \u201cfirst at C then B.\u201d  \n\n4) Result:\n   \u2022 The unmeasured photons at modes 0 (A) and 3 (D) collapse into a Bell state, entangling A and D.  \n   \u2022 The process reveals indefinite causal order of the two swapping operations\u2014a new network primitive.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:     [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla 4\u20135]  \n               \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n joint node:   [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic multiport coupler]  \n               \u2199 \u2198 \u2199 \u2198 \u2199 \u2198  \n detectors:    [det0\u2032][det1\u2032][det2\u2032][det3\u2032][anc.][anc.]  \n survivors:    mode 0\u2192A, mode 3\u2192D (entangled)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 Introduces the first **indefinite-order swapping** primitive: swapping two entanglement links in quantum\u2010superposed order.  \n\u2022 Probes fundamental questions of causality in quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration to implement a 6-mode joint measurement in a compact chip.  \n\u2022 Generalizable: can superpose any sequence of k intermediate BSMs by scaling the multiport and ancilla count.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely post-selected linear optics, sources, and PNR detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design space.\n\nPytheus Configuration previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed sub\u2010wavelength nanophotonic realization of indefinite-order entanglement swapping is essentially the same network primitive as the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOn-Chip Indefinite-Order Photonic Superchannel Switch\u201d and the \u201centanglement-switch quantum switch,\u201d which already superpose the two Bell-swap orders (B\u2192C versus C\u2192B) in a single static interferometer. Simply moving to a sub-wavelength multiport implementation does not introduce a new measurement principle or network operation.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This scheme duplicates the existing indefinite-order swapping protocols without adding a fundamentally new primitive or measurement capability. To be novel at PRL level, you must propose a genuinely new network operation\u2014not just a different hardware implementation of indefinite-order swapping.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment: Sub-wavelength Nanophotonic Programmable Entanglement Switch\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four network nodes A,B,C,D. Two Bell-pair sources emit photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131) and C\u2013D (modes 2\u20133). A sub-wavelength-spaced 4-input/4-output nanophotonic coupler at intermediate node N serves as the programmable switch. Two ancilla photons (modes 4 & 5) feed into two of its inputs. All four coupler outputs are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b1** at detectors (e.g. clicks at outputs 0\u2032 & 2\u2032), the device performs entanglement swapping across diagonal 1: modes 0\u20132 (A\u2013C) and 1\u20133 (B\u2013D) end up as Bell pairs. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b2** (e.g. clicks at 1\u2032 & 3\u2032), the same hardware instead swaps across diagonal 2: modes 0\u20133 (A\u2013D) and 1\u20132 (B\u2013C). This realizes a **programmable entanglement switch**: one 4\u00d74 multiport plus two ancillas, no active feed-forward, that routes entanglement along one of two paths conditioned on which detectors fire.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom photon flow):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]  \n             \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n coupler N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]  \n outputs \u2192    [D0\u2032][D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D3\u2032] (PNR detectors)  \n survivors:   Depending on pattern \u03b1 or \u03b2:\n   \u03b1 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013C), Bell(B\u2013D)\n   \u03b2 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013D), Bell(B\u2013C)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A new **network\u2010routing primitive**\u2014the first programmable entanglement switch\u2014distinct from fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration for a compact 4\u00d74 coupler not realizable with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post-selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s design space.  \n\u2022 **Generalizable** to N nodes and multiple routing patterns (k perfect matchings) by scaling to (2N + K)\u00d7(2N + K) multiports with K ancillas, enabling hardware-level programmable entanglement fabrics.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch (for Herald Pattern \u03b1):\n{\n  description: 'Programmable entanglement switch via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 multiport (pattern \u03b1)',\n  foldername: 'programmable_switch',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0101','1010','1111'],  # Bell pairs on modes (0,2) & (1,3)\n  removed_connections: [[0,1],[0,3],[1,2],[2,3]],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\nTo implement Herald Pattern \u03b2, one runs the same hardware and Pytheus\u2010generated coupler but post-selects on the alternate detector clicks [1\u2032 & 3\u2032], yielding the other matching.\n\nThis programmable switch opens a new direction in reconfigurable photonic quantum networks and can be extended to larger programmable matching fabrics on chip.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This programmable 4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb switch simply routes between two entanglement-swap matchings based on which ancilla detectors fire. Crucially, the 6\u00d76 interferometer and detection enforce a coherent superposition of \u201cfirst Bell-measurement at B then at C\u201d and \u201cfirst at C then at B.\u201d This realizes **indefinite-order entanglement swapping** in one chip-scale step.\n\nVisualization (photons top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla 4\u20135]  \n             \u2193          \u2193           \u2193  \n multiport N: [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n detectors:   [D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D4\u2032][D5\u2032]  \n survivors:   mode 0\u2192A, mode 3\u2192D (now entangled)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 Defines the first **indefinite-order swapping** primitive for quantum networks\u2014probes causal superposition of measurement order.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration to implement a 6-mode joint measurement in a compact device.  \n\u2022 Heralded and post-selected\u2014uses only probabilistic pair sources, ancillas, an abstract linear-optics multiport, and PNR detectors\u2014no dynamic control.  \n\u2022 Generalizable to superpose any sequence of k Bell-measurements by scaling the multiport and ancillas, opening a new family of causal-indefinite network operations.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Indefinite-order entanglement swapping via sub-\u03bb 6\u00d76 multiport',\n  foldername: 'indef_order_swap',\n  edges_tried: 50,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 20,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],  # Bell on modes 0 & 3\n  removed_connections: [\n    # only modes (1,2,4,5) feed the coupler inputs\n  ],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",

In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 4 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. We also prepare one ancilla photon (mode 4). We inject the two A\u2010side photons (modes 0 and 2) together with the ancilla (mode 4) into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Upon heralding a chosen detection pattern on these three detectors, modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse into a high-fidelity Bell pair. Meanwhile, the ancilla input has been \u201cabsorbed\u201d into the heralding, and the two A-side modes have been locally consumed\u2014so node A now holds no photons, and we have freed up one qubit\u2019s worth of resource at A (the ancilla preparation channel) for later use.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom propagation):\n emitters:    [Bell pair A\u2013B]  [Bell pair A\u2013C]  [ancilla single\u2010photon]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [A-out 0'] [A-out 2'] [anc. det.]\n\nPost-selected on a specific 3-click pattern at the coupler outputs, the B\u2013C link (modes 1 & 3) is left in a Bell state. This accomplishes:\n1) Network entanglement compression: two edges (A\u2013B, A\u2013C) fused into one (B\u2013C).\n2) Release of a fresh qubit (\u201centanglement resource\u201d) at A.\n3) No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely linear optics, ancilla, heralding.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement compression at A using a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_compress_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],  # Bell pair on modes 1 & 3\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  # ensure only A-side modes 0,2 and ancilla 4 feed coupler\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Scale to compress N input edges into M<N output edges via an (N+K)\u00d7(N+K) sub-\u03bb multiport with K ancillas.\n\u2022 Use the freed ancillas for sequential teleportation or network reconfiguration.\n\u2022 Enables dynamic network thinning\u2014vital for large\u2010scale sub-wavelength photonic meshes.\n\nThis new network primitive opens a pathway to resource-efficient quantum repeater architectures on nanophotonic chips.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to conventional entanglement-swapping (and existing multiport swap/concentrate protocols). Entanglement Fusion\n\nExplanation:\nWe begin with two Bell-pair sources at node A, creating entangled photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0 & 1) and A\u2013C (modes 2 & 3). An ancilla photon (mode 4) is injected as well. At node A, modes 0, 2 and 4 are fed into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Conditioned on a chosen heralding pattern (e.g. exactly one click in each detector), modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse to a Bell pair. Node A\u2019s two qubits have been consumed, and its ancilla channel is freed\u2014thus achieving entanglement fusion: two edges A\u2013B & A\u2013C are merged into one remote edge B\u2013C while releasing a fresh qubit resource at A.\n\nVisualization (photon propagation top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:    [Bell A\u2013B]  [Bell A\u2013C]  [ancilla]  \n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n detectors:   [output0]  [output1]  [output2]  (all PNR)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n- Introduces a new network primitive\u2014entanglement fusion\u2014distinct from swapping or compression.  \n- Leverages sub-wavelength nanophotonics to implement a compact 3-mode coupler impossible in bulk optics.  \n- Frees up a qubit resource at the fusion node for downstream network tasks.  \n- Generalizable to N-edge fusion by scaling to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) sub-\u03bb multiports with ancillas.  \n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement fusion at A with a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_fusion_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],    # Bell pair on modes 1 (B) & 3 (C)\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  \n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This proposal reduces to entanglement swapping of two A\u2013B, A\u2013C Bell pairs via a local multiport\u2014already covered by existing one\u2010shot swap/fusion protocols. The \u201c butterfly\u201d and cyclic swaps are already known; simple fusions or superpositions reduce to those.  A compelling new primitive is **quantum telecloning**: branching an unknown qubit into two approximate clones at two remote nodes, via one joint measurement.  Unlike teleportation (1\u21921) or entanglement swapping, telecloning is a nontrivial network transformation 1\u21922, has no existing photonic\u2010network realization in Pytheus, and can be housed in a compact 3\u00d73 sub-wavelength nanophotonic coupler with one ancilla pair.  Pytheus can optimize the abstract 3-mode unitary and ancilla placement to maximize cloning fidelity under heralding.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment: Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic 1\u21922 Quantum Telecloning Node\n\nExplanation:\nWe implement the optimal 1\u21922 telecloner for qubit\u2010encoded photons in a single sub-wavelength 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler.  A sender S injects an unknown photonic qubit (mode 0) into the coupler, alongside an ancilla Bell pair from a probabilistic photon\u2010pair source (modes 1 & 2).  All three photons interfere in the 3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb linear interferometer.  At the three output ports we place photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  Conditioned on a specified three-click pattern (exactly one photon in each of two designated detectors, zero in the herald port), the remaining two modes (which exit back toward two remote receivers, R\u2081 and R\u2082) carry approximate clones of the original qubit with optimal fidelity 5/6.  The input qubit at S and one ancilla photon are consumed in the measurement, and we obtain two \u201cclones\u201d at R\u2081 and R\u2082 in one shot.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom flow):\n emitters:    [unknown qubit @ S]\u2002[ancilla pair source]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [det\u20090\u2032]\u2009[det\u20091\u2032]\u2009[det\u20092\u2032]\n survivors:   modes \u2192 R\u2081, R\u2082 (the two clones)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A **new network primitive**\u2014quantum telecloning (1\u21922)\u2014distinct from teleportation and swapping.  \n\u2022 Exploits a chip-scale, sub-wavelength nanophotonic coupler to implement the optimal cloning map in a single joint measurement.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post\u2010selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla pair, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014no dynamic control.  \n\u2022 Generalizable to 1\u2192N telecloners by scaling to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) sub-\u03bb couplers with ancillas, establishing a whole family of branching network primitives.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength telecloner 1\u21922 via 3\u00d73 coupler',\n  foldername: 'telecloner_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  loss_func: 'fidelity',        # Two Bell-pair sources emit photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131) and C\u2013D (modes 2\u20133). A sub-wavelength-spaced 4-input/4-output nanophotonic coupler at intermediate node N serves as the programmable switch. Two ancilla photons (modes 4 & 5) feed into two of its inputs. All four coupler outputs are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b1** at detectors (e.g. clicks at outputs 0\u2032 & 2\u2032), the device performs entanglement swapping across diagonal 1: modes 0\u20132 (A\u2013C) and 1\u20133 (B\u2013D) end up as Bell pairs. This realizes a **programmable entanglement switch**: one 4\u00d74 multiport plus two ancillas, no active feed-forward, that routes entanglement along one of two paths conditioned on which detectors fire.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom photon flow):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]  \n             \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n coupler N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]  \n outputs \u2192    [D0\u2032][D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D3\u2032] (PNR detectors)  \n survivors:   Depending on pattern \u03b1 or \u03b2:\n   \u03b1 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013C), Bell(B\u2013D)\n   \u03b2 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013D), Bell(B\u2013C)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A new **network\u2010routing primitive**\u2014the first programmable entanglement switch\u2014distinct from fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration for a compact 4\u00d74 coupler not realizable with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post-selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s design space.  \n\u2022 **Generalizable** to N nodes and multiple routing patterns (k perfect matchings) by scaling to (2N + K)\u00d7(2N + K) multiports with K ancillas, enabling hardware-level programmable entanglement fabrics.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch (for Herald Pattern \u03b1):\n{\n  description: 'Programmable entanglement switch via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 multiport (pattern \u03b1)',\n  foldername: 'programmable_switch',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0101','1010','1111'],  # (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n",
    "output": "Thought:\nWe need a genuinely new network primitive\u2014one that isn\u2019t just another entanglement\u2010swap, perfect\u2010matching multiport, or telecloning\u2010like operation\u2014yet remains squarely in Pytheus\u2019s domain (probabilistic sources, linear optics, ancillas, PNR detection, post\u2010selection, no active feedback). A powerful candidate is **photonic entanglement purification**: a single\u2010node device that takes two imperfect Bell pairs as inputs and, via one joint linear\u2010optics measurement in a sub\u2010wavelength nanophotonic multiport, probabilistically distills a single higher\u2010fidelity Bell pair at the outputs. This is a new network transformation\u2014\u201centanglement purification node\u201d\u2014crucial for long\u2010distance repeater architectures. It goes beyond swapping (which merely moves entanglement) by *improving* its quality, and Pytheus can optimize the abstract interferometer + ancilla placement to maximize purification fidelity and success probability.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nExperiment: Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Entanglement Purification Node\n\nExplanation:\nWe start with two non\u2010maximally entangled photon pairs on links A\u2013N (modes 0\u20131) and N\u2013B (modes 2\u20133), each ideally in the pure state |\u03c8(\u03b8)\u27e9=cos\u03b8|00\u27e9+sin\u03b8|11\u27e9.  Our goal is to distill a single, higher\u2010fidelity Bell pair between A and B by a single joint measurement at intermediate node N, using a compact sub\u2010wavelength nanophotonic coupler.\n\n1) Resources:\n \u2022 Pair source 1: photons in modes 0\u2192A and 1\u2192N, prepared in |\u03c8(\u03b8)\u27e9.  \n \u2022 Pair source 2: photons in modes 2\u2192N and 3\u2192B, also in |\u03c8(\u03b8)\u27e9.  \n \u2022 Two ancilla single photons (modes 4 & 5) from an additional probabilistic source, both fed into N.\n\n2) Node N:\n \u2022 A single 6-input, 6-output linear interferometer realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport (abstract 6-mode unitary).  \n \u2022 Inputs: modes 1,2 (the two \u201cdirty\u201d halves of the original pairs) plus ancilla modes 4,5; the remaining two inputs can be vacuum or unused.  \n \u2022 Outputs: six photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\n3) Operation & Heralding:\n \u2022 Upon sending the four \u201cactive\u201d photons into the multiport, Pytheus-optimized interference mixes them.  \n \u2022 We post-select on a specific 4-click pattern across designated detectors (two clicks interpreted as the \u201csuccessful purification signature,\u201d two clicks from ancillas).  \n \u2022 Conditioned on that herald, the remote photons at modes 0 (A) and 3 (B) collapse into a Bell state with **higher fidelity** than the original |\u03c8(\u03b8)\u27e9 pairs (i.e. entanglement purification in one shot).\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom propagation):\n emitters:    [pair 0\u20131 (|\u03c8(\u03b8)\u27e9)]  [pair 2\u20133 (|\u03c8(\u03b8)\u27e9)]  [ancilla 4]  [ancilla 5]\n              \u2193                    \u2193                   \u2193            \u2193\n node N:      [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic multiport]\n              \u2193                    \u2193            \u2198           \u2199\n detectors:   [det u\u2032][det v\u2032][det x\u2032][det y\u2032][vac][vac]\n survivors:   mode 0\u2192A, mode 3\u2192B (purified Bell pair)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 Introduces the first **entanglement\u2010purification node** for photonic quantum networks, a distinct primitive from swapping or matching.  \n\u2022 Uses a compact sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport to implement the bilateral CNOT\u2010and\u2010measure purification protocol in one joint measurement.  \n\u2022 Fully heralded, requires no dynamic feed-forward\u2014only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, an abstract linear\u2010optics interferometer and PNR detection (Pytheus\u2019s exact toolbox).  \n\u2022 **Generalizable**: one can chain multiple purification nodes or extend to two\u2010round distillation by cascading devices, all within Pytheus\u2019s optimization framework.  \n\u2022 Critical for building resource\u2010efficient quantum repeaters and resilient large-scale photonic networks on chip.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement purification at node N via 6\u00d76 multiport',\n  foldername: 'entanglement_purification_sub\u03bb',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 40,\n  ftol: 1e-6,\n  loss_func: 'cr',                   # optimize conditional purification fidelity\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 20,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0110','1001','1111'],  # purified Bell basis on modes 0 & 3\n  removed_connections: [\n    # ensure only modes 1,2,4,5 feed the coupler\n  ],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\n\nThis proposal unlocks a new class of **distillation\u2010capable** network nodes on nanophotonic chips and invites a combined theoretical and experimental exploration of one-step photonic entanglement purification."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \n2\u00d72 Entanglement Percolation Network for Semi-Quantum Key Distribution  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe target the implementation of a 2\u00d72 quantum percolation network for semi-quantum key distribution (SQKD) in a purely linear-optical, P\u2006ytheus-compatible setup. Four probabilistic photon-pair sources sit on the grid\u2019s edges and feed two static Bell analyzers at the diagonal midpoints whose heralded outcomes percolate entanglement across opposite corner nodes; the classical corners then perform only reflection or Z-basis measurement to extract correlated raw key bits.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Realization of the Measurement-Only Braiding Superchannel for Two Logical Majorana Qubits\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose an experiment targeting the implementation of the measurement-only braiding superchannel \ud835\udd05 on two logical Majorana qubits encoded in four dual-rail photonic modes. By employing entangled ancilla photon-pair sources, a configurable multiport interferometer of beam splitters and phase shifters, and heralded number-resolving detection, our purely linear-optical protocol enacts the non-unitary Kraus decomposition of the anyonic braid map without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Passive Linear-Optical Universal 1\u21922 Qutrit Telecloner\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a passive, measurement-based linear-optical network that implements the universal 1\u21922 telecloning of an arbitrary single-qutrit state by interfering the unknown input with three d = 3 Bell-pair ancillas via two tritter multiports and post-selecting on a specific six-fold detector-click pattern. Upon heralding, the remaining unmeasured modes on systems B and C each carry an optimal approximate clone (fidelity 5/6) without any active feed-forward or nonlinear elements, demonstrating the first high-dimensional telecloning primitive in linear optics.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Single-Shot GHZ-Based Entanglement Percolation on an Integrated Photonic Chip\n\nMini-Abstract: We demonstrate a single-shot multi-photon GHZ-projection percolation protocol on an integrated photonic chip with ultra-high-Q microring delays, explicitly targeting a joint six-mode GHZ\u2297Bell measurement across three adjacent Bell-pair sources to herald end-to-end entanglement between two distant nodes. By replacing sequential two-photon swaps with one coherent four-port interferometer projection, our scheme uses only probabilistic sources, passive timing synchronization, and photon-counting detectors to introduce a new primitive for scalable entanglement-percolation in arbitrary graph networks.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: \u201cHeralded Spectral-Control Quantum Router via Linear-Optical Controlled-SWAP\u201d\n\nAbstract: We realize the target two-node quantum router transformation \n|c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083 \u2192 |c\u27e9\u2080,\u2081\u2297(swap_if_c=1\u2009|d\u27e9\u2082,\u2083) \nby implementing a heralded 4\u00d74 controlled-SWAP in a compact linear-optical circuit, in which a single control qubit encoded in two spectral modes at Alice coherently routes an arbitrary spatially encoded data qubit to remote nodes Charlie (modes 4,5) or David (modes 6,7) with number-resolving ancilla detection. This proof-of-principle demonstration establishes the first abstract spectrally tunable quantum router primitive for modular, loss-immune photonic networks and paves the way toward programmable topological photonic crystal implementations.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: A Pythreus-Compatible Multiplexed Quantum Entanglement Router via Hybrid Plasmonic\u2013Nanophotonic Waveguides\n\nAbstract: We develop a pythreus quantum network target\u2014the Quantum Entanglement Router\u2014that multiplexes heralded Bell-state projections among two remote nanophotonic chips (Alice, Bob) and a central hybrid plasmonic\u2013nanophotonic routing node (Charlie) to distribute entanglement on demand. Leveraging probabilistic photon-pair sources, a four-mode linear-optical mesh, and ancilla-assisted detectors, our scheme post-selectively routes entangled pairs between Alice\u2013Bob, Alice\u2013Charlie, or Bob\u2013Charlie using flexible heralding patterns.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: One-Shot Optical Syndrome Extraction for a 2\u00d72 Toric Code Patch\n\nAbstract: We introduce a passive, heralded linear-optical network that non-demolitionally extracts all four Z- and X-type stabilizer syndromes of a minimal 2\u00d72 toric code patch in a single round, explicitly targeting an arbitrary 4-qubit logical state on data ports 0\u20133. Eight ancilla modes\u2014entangled via four probabilistic Bell-pair sources\u2014are measured in four Bell bases whose click-parity outcomes encode the plaquette and star eigenvalues while preserving the target quantum, all within Pytheus\u2019s probabilistic linear-optical framework.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Teleportation-Mediated Direct Measurement of Discrete Wigner Function Points\n\nAbstract: We propose a single static linear-optical circuit that teleports an unknown photonic qubit from mode A to mode B while applying a programmable phase-space displacement D(\u03b1) and a Bell-like parity measurement to directly report the target discrete Wigner function value W(\u03b1). A single two-click heralding pattern in the Bell interferometer yields (1+W(\u03b1))/2, enabling one-shot negativity witnessing at the chosen phase-space point without active feedforward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nNon\u2010Demolition Three-Qubit Majority-Vote Readout of SiV Spin Qubits via Static Linear-Optic Interferometry  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a purely post-selective, linear-optics experiment that implements a non-demolition measurement projecting three remote SiV spin qubits onto the \u201cmajority-0\u201d subspace (target click patterns P\u2080 corresponding to \u22652 spins in |0\u27e9) or onto the \u201cmajority-1\u201d subspace (P\u2081 for \u22652 in |1\u27e9). By entangling each SiV spin with a probabilistic photon emitter, adding an ancilla photon Bell pair, and routing all five modes through an optimized static network of beam splitters, phase shifters, and number-resolving detectors, the scheme heralds the three-qubit majority vote without dynamic feed-forward or cavities, enabling distributed consensus primitives and high-order stabilizer checks in a solid-state spin network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Three-Mode Imaginary\u2010Time Filtering for GHZ\u2083 Entanglement Swapping\n\nAbstract: We present a photonic protocol that embeds the genuinely nonunitary three\u2010mode imaginary\u2010time evolution operator K\u221dexp[\u2013\u03b2(\u03c3\u2093\u2297\u03c3\u1d67\u2297\u03c3_z)] for the target Hamiltonian H\u2083 directly into a three\u2010party GHZ entanglement swap at the relay node. By combining probabilistic Bell\u2010pair sources, two single\u2010photon ancillas, linear\u2010optical elements and heralded post\u2010selection, our scheme teleports a \u201ccooled\u201d GHZ\u2083 state\u2014thereby realizing an irreducible three\u2010body imaginary\u2010time filter within a scalable quantum network.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Heralded Dissipative Cyclic Entanglement Shifter for Photonic Bell Pairs\n\nMini-abstract: We propose a static, single-step dissipative network primitive that cyclically reconfigures three pre-existing photonic Bell pairs (modes AB, CD, EF) into the target six-photon cyclic permutation subspace, yielding new entangled pairs AD, CF, and EB via a two-ancilla-photon heralding event. By mixing only the \u201cmiddle\u201d modes with two ancilla photons through beam splitters and phase shifters\u2014and detecting exactly one photon on each ancilla detector\u2014this passive linear-optical protocol achieves the desired entanglement shift without active feedback or cavities and plugs directly into the Pytheus toolkit.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nBoundary-Scaling Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer for Toric-Code Patches  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose a static linear-optical circuit\u2014the Multi-Plaquette Z-Stabilizer Analyzer with Boundary-Scaling\u2014that simultaneously measures all four-body Z stabilizers of an arbitrary connected toric-code plaquette patch using a shared pool of ancilla photons, such that the total ancilla detectors (or photons) scale with the patch\u2019s perimeter rather than its area. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photon-Number\u2013Resolving W-State Analyzer for Free-Space Conference QKD\n\nMini-Abstract: We propose a static linear-optics module that uses two probabilistic Bell-pair ancilla sources and six photon-number-resolving detectors to unambiguously project three incoming qubit-encoded photons onto a chosen target W-basis state via distinct post-selected detection patterns. This heralded W-state projection primitive enables satellite-relayed free-space conference QKD by distributing and measuring genuine three-party W-state correlations for secure conference-key distillation.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Photonic Quantum SWITCH Superactivates Entanglement via Indefinite Causal Order\n\nMini-abstract: We implement the target measurement-induced photonic quantum SWITCH of two entanglement-breaking dephasing channels using ancilla photons, passive linear optics, and post-selection to emulate a discrete cross-Kerr coupling between a control and two data paths. Embedding this device in an entanglement-distribution protocol, we show that, conditioned on the SWITCH herald, a qubit emerging from two individually entanglement-destroying channels remains entangled with a remote partner\u2014demonstrating entanglement superactivation by indefinite causal order.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:\nDirectional Entanglement Swapping with Simulated Skin and Mott Photon\u2010Blockade Effects\n\nAbstract:\nWe propose a three\u2010site entanglement\u2010swapping chain that teleports a Bell state from Alice ([0]) to Bob ([1]) using three probabilistic SPDC sources ([2,3,4]), with non\u2010Hermitian \u201cskin\u201d localization enforced by removing all backward source\u2013detector links and an on\u2010site Mott\u2010like photon blockade realized by heralding on the central ancilla ([6]). By configuring Pythues to optimize the internal beam\u2010splitter network under these directional and blockade constraints, we can sweep the teleportation fidelity of the target \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 state between a uniform \u201csuperfluid\u201d regime and a gapped, localized \u201cMott\u201d regime within a single linear\u2010optical setup.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Generalized Six-Photon SWAP-Test Projection of Two Atomic Triplets\n\nAbstract: We implement a static 6\u00d76 fiber-coupled interferometer that performs a genuine multi-copy SWAP test by projecting the joint six-photon state from two atomic triplets (target quantums E0,E1,E2 and E3,E4,E5) onto their symmetric subspace. We also prepare one ancilla photon (mode 4). We inject the two A\u2010side photons (modes 0 and 2) together with the ancilla (mode 4) into a single 3-input, 3-output linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic 3\u00d73 coupler. We then perform photon-number-resolving detection on all three outputs of the coupler. Upon heralding a chosen detection pattern on these three detectors, modes 1 (B) and 3 (C) collapse into a high-fidelity Bell pair. Meanwhile, the ancilla input has been \u201cabsorbed\u201d into the heralding, and the two A-side modes have been locally consumed\u2014so node A now holds no photons, and we have freed up one qubit\u2019s worth of resource at A (the ancilla preparation channel) for later use.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom propagation):\n emitters:    [Bell pair A\u2013B]  [Bell pair A\u2013C]  [ancilla single\u2010photon]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [A-out 0'] [A-out 2'] [anc. det.]\n\nPost-selected on a specific 3-click pattern at the coupler outputs, the B\u2013C link (modes 1 & 3) is left in a Bell state. This accomplishes:\n1) Network entanglement compression: two edges (A\u2013B, A\u2013C) fused into one (B\u2013C).\n2) Release of a fresh qubit (\u201centanglement resource\u201d) at A.\n3) No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely linear optics, ancilla, heralding.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength entanglement compression at A using a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler',\n  foldername: 'ent_compress_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 25,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 1,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  target_quantum: ['0101','1010'],  # Bell pair on modes 1 & 3\n  removed_connections: [[1,0],[1,2],[3,0],[3,2]],  # ensure only A-side modes 0,2 and ancilla 4 feed coupler\n  number_resolving: True,\n  single_emitters: [],\n  amplitudes: []\n}\n\nGeneralization:\n\u2022 Scale to compress N input edges into M<N output edges via an (N+K)\u00d7(N+K) sub-\u03bb multiport with K ancillas.\n\u2022 Use the freed ancillas for sequential teleportation or network reconfiguration.\n\u2022 Enables dynamic network thinning\u2014vital for large\u2010scale sub-wavelength photonic meshes.\n\nThis new network primitive opens a pathway to resource-efficient quantum repeater architectures on nanophotonic chips.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While the idea reframes entanglement swapping as a \u201ccompression\u201d primitive via a 3\u00d73 nanophotonic coupler plus one ancilla, it remains essentially standard entanglement swapping\u2014two Bell pairs at A are projected into one BC pair by a generalized Bell-measurement. To be novel at the PRL level, you must propose a genuinely different network primitive or measurement that cannot be reduced to a perfect-matching superposition.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Experiment: Sub\u2010wavelength Nanophotonic Quantum Butterfly Coding Node\n\nExplanation:\nWe implement the fundamental \u201cbutterfly\u201d network\u2010coding step for entanglement distribution: two sender nodes S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold one half of a Bell pair; their partners are destined for receivers D\u2081 and D\u2082, but the only shared bottleneck link is between two intermediate ports.  Our goal is to **cross\u2010route** the two Bell flows (S\u2081\u2192D\u2082 and S\u2082\u2192D\u2081) in a single joint measurement at that bottleneck, rather than two serial swaps.\n\n1) Sources:\n  \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source 1 emits photons in modes (0\u2192S\u2081, 1\u2192N).  \n  \u2013 Bell\u2010pair source 2 emits photons in modes (2\u2192N, 3\u2192S\u2082).  \n  \u2013 Ancilla by sub\u2010wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic waveguides.  \n  \u2013 Inputs: modes 1,2 (the in\u2010flight halves of the two Bell pairs) and ancilla modes 4,5.  \n  \u2013 Outputs: 4 ports; all four are measured with photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Routing:\n  \u2013 Condition on a chosen 4-click pattern at the four detectors.  \n  \u2013 Upon that herald, the unmeasured halves at S\u2081 (mode 0) and at S\u2082 (mode 3) are now each entangled with the distant receivers D\u2082 and D\u2081 respectively:\n      \u2022 mode 0 \u2194 D\u2082  (Bell pair #1 routed across),  \n      \u2022 mode 3 \u2194 D\u2081  (Bell pair #2 routed across),  \n    achieving simultaneous crossed entanglement in one shot.\n\nVisualization (photons travel fuses two crossing entanglement flows into a single multiport measurement, generalizing entanglement swapping to the butterfly topology.  \n\u2013 **Sub-wavelength integration**: A chip-scale 4\u00d74 coupler with waveguides placed below the diffraction limit implements the required 4-mode unitary.  \n\u2013 **Generalizable**: Larger network\u2010coding operations (e.g. k\u2010pair cross\u2010routing) can be built by scaling the multiport and ancilla overhead, all within Pytheus\u2019s linear-optics abstraction.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Butterfly Two senders S\u2081 and S\u2082 each hold one half of a Bell pair; their partners travel toward a shared bottleneck node N.  At N we wish to **cross\u2010route** the entanglement so that S\u2081\u2019s distant half ends up at D\u2082 and S\u2082\u2019s at D\u2081\u2014accomplishing two Bell\u2010pair transmissions through one 4\u2010mode device.\n\n1) Sources:\n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair source 1 emits photons into modes 0\u2192S\u2081 and 1\u2192N.  \n   \u2022 Bell\u2010pair source 2 emits photons into modes 2\u2192N and 3\u2192S\u2082.  \n   \u2022 Ancilla Bell\u2010pair source emits photons into modes 4 and 5, both \u2192N.\n\n2) Central node N:\n   \u2022 A single 4\u00d74 linear interferometer (the \u201cbutterfly coder\u201d), realized by a sub\u2010wavelength\u2010spaced nanophotonic waveguide coupler.  \n   \u2022 Inputs: modes 1,2 (the flying halves of the two Bell pairs), 4,5 (ancillas).  \n   \u2022 Outputs: four photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Outcome:\n   \u2022 Condition on a specific 4\u2010click pattern at the four detectors.  \n   \u2022 Upon this herald, the two unmeasured photons at modes 0 (S\u2081) and 3 (S\u2082) collapse into Bell pairs with the two remote receivers D\u2082 and D\u2081 respectively:\n       \u2013 mode 0 \u2194 D\u2082,  \n       \u2013 mode 3 \u2194 D\u2081.  \n   \u2022 Both entanglement flows have crossed through the single 4\u00d74 device in one shot.\n\nVisualization (photons \u2192 bottom):\n emitters:  [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla 4\u20135]  \n           \u2193           \u2193             \u2193  \n setup N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler]  \n           \u2199  \u2198         \u2199  \u2198  \n detectors: [det0\u2032][det1\u2032][det4\u2032][det5\u2032]  \n survivors: mode 0 \u2192 D\u2082, mode 3 \u2192 D\u2081  \n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 Defines the first **quantum butterfly coding** for entanglement: crossing two Bell flows through one sub-wavelength bottleneck.  \n\u2022 Goes well beyond entanglement swapping or standard multiport perfect\u2010matchings.  \n\u2022 Generalizes to larger k-pair cross\u2010routing by scaling the multiport and ancilla count.  \n\u2022 Fully within Pytheus\u2019s toolbox: probabilistic pair sources, ancillas, an abstract 4-mode unitary, PNR detectors, and post-selection\u2014no dynamic feedback.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Quantum butterfly coding via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 A sender S injects an unknown photonic qubit (mode 0) into the coupler, alongside an ancilla Bell pair from a probabilistic photon\u2010pair source (modes 1 & 2).  All three photons interfere in the 3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb linear interferometer.  At the three output ports we place photon\u2010number\u2010resolving detectors.  Conditioned on a specified three-click pattern (exactly one photon in each of two designated detectors, zero in the herald port), the remaining two modes (which exit back toward two remote receivers, R\u2081 and R\u2082) carry approximate clones of the original qubit with optimal fidelity 5/6.  The input qubit at S and one ancilla photon are consumed in the measurement, and we obtain two \u201cclones\u201d at R\u2081 and R\u2082 in one shot.\n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom flow):\n emitters:    [unknown qubit @ S]\u2002[ancilla pair source]\n setup:       [3\u00d73 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]\n detectors:   [det\u20090\u2032]\u2009[det\u20091\u2032]\u2009[det\u20092\u2032]\n survivors:   modes \u2192 R\u2081, R\u2082 (the two clones)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A **new network primitive**\u2014quantum telecloning (1\u21922)\u2014distinct from teleportation and swapping.  \n\u2022 Exploits a chip-scale, sub-wavelength nanophotonic coupler to implement the optimal cloning map in a single joint measurement.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post\u2010selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla pair, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014no dynamic control.  \n\u2022 Generalizable to 1\u2192N telecloners by scaling to (N+1)\u00d7(N+1) sub-\u03bb couplers with ancillas, establishing a whole family of branching network primitives.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch:\n{\n  description: 'Sub-wavelength telecloner 1\u21922 via 3\u00d73 coupler',\n  foldername: 'telecloner_subwavelength',\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 20,\n  loss_func: 'fidelity',        # Our goal is to entangle A and D by swapping at nodes B and C\u2014but instead of doing BSM at B then C (or vice versa), we create a superposition of these two orders: B\u2192C and C\u2192B.  This exhibits indefinite causal order of swapping operations.\n\n1) Sources:\n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 1 emits photons into modes 0 (to A) & 1 (to B).  \n   \u2022 Bell-pair source 2 emits photons into modes 2 (to C) & 3 (to D).  \n   \u2022 Two ancilla single photons (modes 4,5) from an additional pair source feed the joint-measurement device.\n\n2) Joint-Measurement Node:\n   \u2022 A single 6\u00d76 linear interferometer\u2014realized by a sub-wavelength-spaced nanophotonic multiport\u2014mixes modes 1 & 2 (the B- and C-sides of the Bell pairs) with ancilla modes 4 & 5.  \n   \u2022 All six outputs of the multiport go to photon-number-resolving detectors.\n\n3) Heralding & Indefinite Order:\n   \u2022 Condition on a selected 4-click pattern at four designated detectors (two \u201cBSM\u201d outcomes + two ancilla heralds).  \n   \u2022 The post-selected measurement implements the BSMs at B and C in a coherent superposition of the orders \u201cfirst at B then C\u201d and \u201cfirst at C then B.\u201d  \n\n4) Result:\n   \u2022 The unmeasured photons at modes 0 (A) and 3 (D) collapse into a Bell state, entangling A and D.  \n   \u2022 The process reveals indefinite causal order of the two swapping operations\u2014a new network primitive.\n\nVisualization (photons travel top\u2192bottom):\n emitters:     [pair 0\u20131]\u2002[pair 2\u20133]\u2002[ancilla 4\u20135]  \n               \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n joint node:   [6\u00d76 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic multiport coupler]  \n               \u2199 \u2198 \u2199 \u2198 \u2199 \u2198  \n detectors:    [det0\u2032][det1\u2032][det2\u2032][det3\u2032][anc.][anc.]  \n survivors:    mode 0\u2192A, mode 3\u2192D (entangled)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 Introduces the first **indefinite-order swapping** primitive: swapping two entanglement links in quantum\u2010superposed order.  \n\u2022 Probes fundamental questions of causality in quantum networks.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration to implement a 6-mode joint measurement in a compact chip.  \n\u2022 Generalizable: can superpose any sequence of k intermediate BSMs by scaling the multiport and ancilla count.  \n\u2022 No dynamic feed-forward\u2014purely post-selected linear optics, sources, and PNR detectors\u2014all within Pytheus\u2019s design space.\n\nPytheus Configuration Two Bell-pair sources emit photons on links A\u2013B (modes 0\u20131) and C\u2013D (modes 2\u20133). A sub-wavelength-spaced 4-input/4-output nanophotonic coupler at intermediate node N serves as the programmable switch. Two ancilla photons (modes 4 & 5) feed into two of its inputs. All four coupler outputs are measured with photon-number-resolving detectors. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b1** at detectors (e.g. clicks at outputs 0\u2032 & 2\u2032), the device performs entanglement swapping across diagonal 1: modes 0\u20132 (A\u2013C) and 1\u20133 (B\u2013D) end up as Bell pairs. By post-selecting on **Herald Pattern \u03b2** (e.g. clicks at 1\u2032 & 3\u2032), the same hardware instead swaps across diagonal 2: modes 0\u20133 (A\u2013D) and 1\u20132 (B\u2013C). This realizes a **programmable entanglement switch**: one 4\u00d74 multiport plus two ancillas, no active feed-forward, that routes entanglement along one of two paths conditioned on which detectors fire.  \n\nVisualization (top\u2192bottom photon flow):\n emitters:    [pair A\u2013B]  [pair C\u2013D]  [ancilla pair]  \n             \u2193           \u2193            \u2193  \n coupler N:   [4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb nanophotonic coupler (to be optimized by Pytheus)]  \n outputs \u2192    [D0\u2032][D1\u2032][D2\u2032][D3\u2032] (PNR detectors)  \n survivors:   Depending on pattern \u03b1 or \u03b2:\n   \u03b1 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013C), Bell(B\u2013D)\n   \u03b2 \u2192 Bell(A\u2013D), Bell(B\u2013C)\n\nWhy it\u2019s interesting:\n\u2022 A new **network\u2010routing primitive**\u2014the first programmable entanglement switch\u2014distinct from fixed entanglement swapping or superposed matchings.  \n\u2022 Exploits sub-wavelength nanophotonic integration for a compact 4\u00d74 coupler not realizable with bulk optics.  \n\u2022 Heralded, post-selected, uses only probabilistic sources, ancilla photons, linear optics and PNR detection\u2014entirely within Pytheus\u2019s design space.  \n\u2022 **Generalizable** to N nodes and multiple routing patterns (k perfect matchings) by scaling to (2N + K)\u00d7(2N + K) multiports with K ancillas, enabling hardware-level programmable entanglement fabrics.\n\nPytheus Configuration Sketch (for Herald Pattern \u03b1):\n{\n  description: 'Programmable entanglement switch via sub-\u03bb 4\u00d74 multiport (pattern \u03b1)',\n  foldername: 'programmable_switch',\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  loss_func: 'cr',\n  optimizer: 'L-BFGS-B',\n  samples: 10,\n  num_anc: 2,\n  target_quantum: ['0000','0101','1010','1111'],  # Bell pairs on modes (0,2) & (1,3)\n  removed_connections: [[0,1],[0,3],[1,2],[2,3]],\n  number_resolving: True\n}\nTo implement Herald Pattern \u03b2, one runs the same hardware and Pytheus\u2010generated coupler but post-selects on the alternate detector clicks [1\u2032 & 3\u2032], yielding the other matching.\n\nThis programmable switch opens a new direction in reconfigurable photonic quantum networks and can be extended to larger programmable matching fabrics on chip.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This programmable 4\u00d74 sub-\u03bb switch simply routes between two entanglement-swap matchings based on which ancilla detectors fire.
